note.p: Birth: Nice, France (10 October 1731)
Death: London (24 February 1810)
Burial: All Saints' Church, Derby (12 March 1810)
Research Field: Natural philosophy
Education: School at Hackney; Peterhouse, Cambridge (admitted 1749, resided until 1753)

Career: Discovered the extreme lightness of inflammatory air (hydrogen) and later ascertained that water is composed of two gases; experimented on electricity and the density of the earth; Sir Everard Home (FRS 1787) was called to see him shortly before he died; left a fortune of over Â£1million
Memberships: FSA
Membership: Fellow
Election Date: 1/05/1760
Medals/Prizes: Copley Medal 1766
Sources: Bulloch's Roll; DNB; DSB; Venn
References: J S Rowlinson, 'Aristocratic Physics', review of Christa Jungnickel and Russell McCormmach, Cavendish in NR 1998 vol 52 pp 194-196
